data.title: Reading Frank Miller’s Old Stuff
data.meta_description: I’ve ragged on Frank Miller a couple of times  for being the crazy grandpa of comic books. This is mostly because his output between the late 90s to mid-2000s were questionable at best…
data.text:
Daredevil | Comic Books

I’ve ragged on Frank Miller a couple of times on this blog for being the crazy grandpa of comic books. This is mostly because his output between the late 90s to mid-2000s were questionable at best and outright racist at worst.

In fact, it used to be popular to dunk on this guy, thanks in part to Linkara, and I’ll admit that I hopped on that internet bandwagon myself. Sure, I liked The Dark Knight Returns alright, but was disappointed with his other stuff. Therefore, I decided to file Frank Miller under “artists who are famous for reasons I can’t understand” and called it a day.

It wasn’t until I did that article on Solomon Kane that I thought of Frank Miller again and felt a little guilty. While he’s considered an old coot now, he’s still a big name in the industry who’s held in high regard by old-school comic fans.

He isn’t famous for no reason. He earned that respect from somewhere. Realizing this, I decided it was time to give Frank Miller a fair shake. After all, it’s easy to judge an artist on his worst art. It takes effort to examine their best works and understand why they’re good.

Going off the recommendations of YouTubers and members of r/graphicnovels, I picked out some of Miller’s “best” comics to read for myself. Maybe I still won’t…
